column3: A king promised his dying wife that he would not re-marry unless it was to a woman who was as beautiful as she was, and when he looked for a new wife, he realized that the only woman that could match her beauty was his own daughter.The daughter tried to make the wedding impossible by asking for three dresses, one as golden as the sun, one as silver as the moon, and one as dazzling as the stars, and a mantle made from the fur of every kind of bird and animal in the kingdom. When her father provided them, she took them, with a gold ring, a gold spindle, and a gold reel, and ran from the castle the night before the wedding.She ran far away to another kingdom, and slept in a great forest there, but the young king of that place and his dogs found her while he was hunting. She asked the king to have pity on her and received a place in the kitchen, where she worked, and because she gave no name she was called "All-Kinds-of-Fur."When the king held a ball, she snuck out and went to it in her golden dress. The next morning, the cook set her to make soup for the king, and she put her golden ring in it. The king found it and questioned the cook and then All-Kinds-of-Fur, but she revealed nothing. The next ball, she went dressed in her silver dress and put the golden spindle in the soup, and the king again could discover nothing.The third ball, she went in the star dress, and the king slipped a golden ring on her finger without her noticing it and ordered that the last dance go longer than usual. She was not able to get away in time to change; she was able only to throw her fur mantle over her clothing before she had to cook the soup. When the king questioned her, he caught her hand, seeing the ring, and when she tried to pull it away, her mantle slipped, revealing the dress of stars. The king pulled off the mantle, revealing her, and they married.
column4: princess (hero), king (antagonist), another realm's young king (donor)
column6: the daughter's escape from her father's marriage proposal leads her to disguise herself. the young king's discovery of her identity changes their fates.
column7: Allerleirauh  A beautiful princess is forced to flee her stepmother's wrath after her father dies. She disguises herself as a scullery maid named Allerleirauh, wearing magical garb: a golden cloak, a silver robe, and a star-strewn veil.  Allerleirauh works tirelessly in the castle, but her beauty captivates the king's son. He falls madly in love with her and insists on marrying her despite her claims of being a mere servant.  On her wedding night, Allerleirauh secretly wears one of her magical garments each night, revealing her true beauty. The king's son is overjoyed but perplexed by the disappearance of his bride each morning.  One night, he spies Allerleirauh in her star-strewn veil and recognizes her as the princess he had once glimpsed. Allerleirauh's stepmother's wicked plot is unmasked, and she is banished.  Allerleirauh and the prince marry happily, and she wears her magical cloak, robe, and veil at their wedding, symbolizing her transformation from a servant to a princess.
column8: beginning from other version/gets mixed with Cinderella?
column9: Allerleirauh  Once upon a time, in a grand castle nestled amidst towering mountains, lived a beautiful princess named Allerleirauh. Her father, the King, was a cruel and selfish man who harbored an unspoken love for his own daughter. When Allerleirauh refused his advances, he grew furious and banished her from the kingdom.  Heartbroken and alone, Allerleirauh wandered into the depths of a vast forest. As she stumbled through the undergrowth, she came across a magnificent stag. With gentle eyes, the stag led her to a secluded clearing where she discovered a tiny cottage.  Inside the cottage lived an elderly woman who took pity on Allerleirauh. She offered her shelter and a new identity. Allerleirauh disguised herself as a servant girl named Aschenputtel, covering her golden hair and delicate features in grime.  Meanwhile, in a distant realm, rumors of Allerleirauh's beauty had reached the ears of a young king. Determined to find her, he traveled far and wide. One evening, he came across a grand ball at the King's castle.  As Allerleirauh watched from the sidelines, the young king's gaze fell upon her. Despite her humble attire, he recognized the princess beneath the layers of dirt. Intrigued, he invited her to dance.  As they twirled across the ballroom floor, Allerleirauh's secret was revealed when a hazelnut fell from her pocket. Her father recognized the nut as a token he had given her years ago.  Enraged, the King ordered Aschenputtel to be seized. However, the young king intervened, promising to marry the mysterious servant girl.  Together, Allerleirauh and the young king left the cursed kingdom and returned to his own realm. Their love story became a legend, reminding all that true beauty lies not in outward appearance but in the purity of one's heart.
column10: moralist attitude, explicit mix with Cinderella, but in name only, added helper

column3: a magician shows a rooster carrying a beam. a girl carrying a four-leafed clover realizes and declares that it is just a straw, not a beam. when she marries, the magician enchants her to think she sees a stream and then breaks it after she has hiked up her skirts to cross.
column6: a magician performs a trick, a girl exposes him. the magician later takes his revenge on the girl.
column7: In the Grimm fairy tale "The Beam," a poor girl named Trinchen (Catherine) is orphaned and must fend for herself. Desperate for shelter, she stumbles upon a mysterious house in the forest.  Inside the house, she finds an old woman who offers her shelter in exchange for housework. Trinchen agrees and diligently performs her duties. However, the old woman is a witch who treats her cruelly, forcing her to do endless chores and giving her hardly any food.  One day, Trinchen discovers a large piece of gold hanging in the attic. She takes it to the old woman, hoping for some gratitude. However, the witch becomes enraged and accuses her of theft. She threatens to beat Trinchen within an inch of her life.  Terrified, Trinchen runs away from the house and into the forest. She encounters a prince who offers her protection. The prince takes her to his castle, where she becomes his loyal servant.  Meanwhile, the old witch, driven by greed, follows Trinchen to the castle. She tries to turn Trinchen into a dove, but the prince's prayers protect her. The witch is then forced to flee, and Trinchen lives happily ever after in the castle.
column9: The Beam  Once upon a time, in a realm unknown, there lived a cunning magician named Eldrin. With his captivating words and nimble hands, he performed extraordinary illusions, leaving audiences in awe.  Among his most impressive tricks was "The Beam of Truth." Eldrin would summon a blinding beam of light that supposedly revealed the hidden intentions of others. As the beam illuminated the crowd, Eldrin would expose the secrets of the guilty and humiliate those who lied.  However, one day, a young girl named Anya dared to challenge Eldrin. With keen eyes and a sharp mind, she noticed that the beam's source was a concealed mirror that projected the magician's own reflections.  Undaunted, Anya confronted Eldrin, exposing his deception in front of the astonished crowd. Humiliated and furious, Eldrin vowed revenge.  Later that night, as Anya walked through the lonely streets, Eldrin cast a curse upon her. He cursed her with forgetfulness, causing her to lose all memory of his trick and the subsequent confrontation.  As years passed, Anya lived a seemingly ordinary life, unaware of the darkness that lurked within. But one fateful day, as she gazed into an old, dusty mirror, a flash of memory returned. The shame and fear washed over her as she remembered the day she exposed Eldrin's secret.  And so, Eldrin's vengeance was complete. Anya, once a beacon of truth, now bore the burden of a forgotten past, haunted by the consequences of facing the wrath of a vengeful magician.
column10: fantasy influences in naming of characters and items (Eldrin, Anya, Beam of Truth) - the beam recognised as central element for the trick

column3: A man serves as a soldier, but when the war ends, he returns home to learn that both of his parents have died and that his brothers have no place for him.While walking in a heath, the soldier meets a man with a green coat and a horse's hoof before shooting a bear that is charging at them. The Devil then offers to make the soldier rich if for seven years, he will neither cut his hair, clip his nails, bathe, nor cite the Lord's Prayer, and wear a coat and cloak. If the soldier survives, he will be rich and free but if he dies, the Devil will claim his soul. The desperate soldier agrees, and the Devil makes him wear both the green coat - telling him he will find its pockets always full of money - and the dead bear's skin, telling him that he must sleep in it and will be known as Bearskin because of it.Bearskin sets out, donating money to the poor and asking them to pray for him to live out the seven years. After three years, Bearskin becomes so revolting that he must pay heavily to get any shelter. In the fourth year, he hears an old man lamenting and persuades him to tell his tale: the old man has lost all his money and does not know how to provide for his three daughters nor pay the innkeeper, so he will be jailed. Bearskin pays the innkeeper and gives the old man a purse of gold as well. The old man thanks Bearskin by allowing him to marry any of his three daughters. The oldest daughter runs away in fear. The middle one says that Bearskin is worse than an actual bear passing off as human. The youngest daughter agrees to fulfill her father's promise. Bearskin gives his fiancée one half of a ring and promises to return in three years. The maiden then dresses in black, waiting for her betrothed as her sisters mock her endlessly.At the end of the seven years, Bearskin finds the Devil again and demands that he fulfill his promise. The Devil then proceeds to bathe Bearskin, clip his nails, cut his hair, and say the Lord's Prayer. The Devil warns Bearskin not to push his luck, as he has already won their bargain, and disappears. Clean and rich, Bearskin dresses himself as a fine gentleman and goes to the old man's house, where the older sisters serve him, but his bride does not recognize him. Bearskin tells the old man that he will marry one of his daughters. The two older sisters run off to dress splendidly, and Bearskin drops his half of the ring into a wine cup and gives it to his bride. She drinks the wine and upon finding the half ring, realizes that he is her bridegroom and they marry.When they realize that Bearskin is the suitor they had rejected, one sister hangs herself in a rage and the other drowns herself. That night, the Devil knocks on the door to tell Bearskin that he has gotten two souls for the price of one.
column4: soldier (hero), devil (antagonist). old man, man's three daughters
column5: heath, old man's inn, old man's house
column6: a soldier encounters the devil on a heath and strikes a deal for wealth and a cursed appearance. he helps a destitute old man and wins the promise of marriage from his youngest daughter.
column7: Bearskin  Once upon a time, a young man sets out to seek his fortune. He meets three old men who demand his bag, jacket, and hat. In exchange, they grant him three wishes: the ability to turn into a bearskin at will, an enchanted club that defeats all foes, and a limitless supply of gold.  The young man uses his wishes to make a fortune and win a beautiful princess. However, he must keep his bearskin form a secret from her. When she discovers the truth, she is horrified and runs away.  Desperate, the young man stays in his bearskin form and wanders the forest. He encounters a witch who reveals that the princess has been kidnapped by a dragon. The bearskin uses his club to defeat the dragon and rescue the princess.  As a reward, the king offers the young man his daughter's hand in marriage. The witch grants him the gift of speech, and the couple lives happily ever after.
column8: not reproduced faithfully, but bearskin identified as central topic
column9: The Soldier and the Devil's Bearskin  Once upon a time, in a desolate heath, a weary soldier met the devil. Desperate for fortune, he struck a deal with him. The devil gave him a cursed bearskin that would grant him wealth but also deform his appearance.  The soldier, now adorned in the grotesque bearskin, stumbled upon an inn owned by an impoverished old man. Moved by the man's plight, he offered his assistance. In gratitude, the old man promised him the hand of his youngest daughter, Elara, who was renowned for her beauty and kindness.  However, the devil's curse had an unforeseen consequence. The soldier's true form was concealed by the bearskin, leaving Elara unaware of his handsome features. Despite his hideous appearance, she fell in love with his gentle heart.  One fateful night, as the soldier and Elara sat by the fire, her curiosity overcame her. She lifted a corner of the bearskin and caught a glimpse of the man beneath. To her surprise, he was not the deformed creature she had imagined, but rather a handsome and valiant soldier.  Overjoyed, Elara vowed to marry the soldier regardless of his appearance. The devil's curse was broken, and the soldier regained his true form. Together, they lived happily ever after, proving that love conquers all, even the most sinister of curses.

column3: A soldier has been discharged from the king's service because of his wounds. The soldier leaves the castle and, as night falls, he requires somewhere to stay. Encountering the home of a witch, he asks her for lodging. The witch agrees on condition that he spade her garden the next day. This takes so long that he must stay another night, and in return she asks him to chop her wood. Once again, he must stay another night.The following day, she requests that he go into a well and retrieve her blue light for her. He is in the process of doing so, but realizes he is being tricked and will be trapped in the well as soon as he gives it to her. He keeps the light for himself, not knowing what it is, but she leaves him in the well. He decides to smoke one last time and lights his pipe with the blue light. A dwarf comes to grant him whatever he wishes. He first asks to be led out of the well, then for the witch to be taken to jail and hanged.To retaliate against the king, the soldier commands the dwarf to bring him the princess so she can act as his maid. When she wakes up, the princess tells her father of her strange "dream", which the king believes could have actually happened. He has the princess fill her pocket with peas and put a little hole in it so that if she actually is carried away they will be able to follow the path.The dwarf, however, notices, and spreads peas all over the city so that the peas lead to everywhere and cannot pin it on the soldier. The next night, she plans on hiding her shoe in the home to which she is taken. The dwarf warns against this to the soldier, but he does not heed it. The next day, the princess's shoe is found in his quarters and he is taken to jail. He sends his friend to get the blue light and as his final request asks for a last smoke of his pipe. The dwarf appears and kills the henchmen; the soldier also demands the king's life, but spares him after he begs for mercy. The soldier marries the princess and takes the throne.
column4: soldier (hero), witch (antagonist), spirit in the blue light (helper), princess, king,
column6: a discharged soldier seeks shelter at a witch's home but becomes trapped. the spirit in the blue light helps him escape and steal a princess away.
column7: The Blue Light  Once upon a time, there were three brothers who inherited their father's forge and a blue light that could conjure gold. The brothers alternated who would guard the light, but each would succumb to greed and use it for themselves. As punishment, the light would burn their hands until they gave the gold away.  One day, the youngest brother, who was the most virtuous, guarded the light. He resisted temptation and remained loyal to his brothers. A poor man appeared and asked for help. The youngest brother used the light to conjure gold and gave it to the man, who turned out to be Jesus.  To reward the youngest brother's kindness, Jesus gave him a piece of coal that could perform miracles. With the coal, the brother healed the king's blind daughter, married her, and became the royal goldsmith. However, his brothers were jealous and stole the coal.  When the brothers used the coal for selfish purposes, it burned them and transformed them into stone statues. The youngest brother and his wife lived happily ever after, while the greedy brothers remained as a warning against greed and dishonesty.
column8: not in KB, so completely random retelling with very non-fairy tale element (Jesus)
column9: The Blue Light  Once upon a time, a weary soldier named Ethan roamed the countryside after being discharged from the king's army. Night fell, and he stumbled upon a desolate castle. Desperate for shelter, he knocked on its heavy gates.  An aged and sinister witch answered, inviting him inside. Unbeknownst to Ethan, her home was a trap. As he stepped across the threshold, the gates slammed shut behind him, and he found himself trapped.  Days turned into nights as the witch held Ethan captive, forcing him to toil. One evening, as Ethan stood by the well in the castle courtyard, he noticed a faint blue light flickering within its depths.  Curiosity overcame him, and he peered into the water. To his astonishment, he saw a beautiful spirit enveloped in a soft, ethereal glow. The spirit whispered words of hope and promised to help him escape the witch's clutches.  Night after night, the spirit guided Ethan, leading him through secret passages and revealing the witch's weakness. Finally, the time came for Ethan to make his daring escape.  Under the cover of darkness, he crept into the witch's lair and found the room where the princess was held prisoner. The spirit in the blue light illuminated her cell, revealing her gentle eyes and flowing golden hair.  Ethan quickly freed the princess, and together they fled the castle. As they ran through the moonlit woods, the witch pursued them, but the spirit in the blue light formed a protective barrier around them, keeping her at bay.  At long last, they reached the king's castle. Ethan was hailed as a hero for rescuing the princess, and the king rewarded him handsomely. The spirit in the blue light vanished, its mission accomplished, leaving behind a legacy of hope and a reminder that even in the darkest of times, help can come from unexpected sources.

column3: A soldier, renowned for his braveness, has just been relieved from the army. He owns an old rain coat and boots in buffalo leather. During his voyage he meets a huntsman in the woods; they are both lost. They decide to travel along together and see a house in the distance. An old woman opens the door and tells them it's a robbers' den, but the men still decide to stay, despite the huntsmen's objections. The woman hides them, but when the 12 robbers arrive home the soldier deliberately coughs to be noticed and they are immediately taken prisoner. The soldier remains calm and tells the robbers that he and his friend want to eat and drink first. The robbers allow this and after the soldier has dined he brandishes the contents of a wine bottle over the robbers' heads and says a magic spell that freezes them all, as if they were turned in stone.The soldier and the huntsman then go to the local town to get some of the soldiers' old friends, bring them to the den and lifts the magic spell, causing the robbers to be able to move again, but they are immediately arrested and sent to prison. As the soldier and the huntsmen return with the imprisoned thieves they are greeted by a joyous crowd of people. The soldier wonders why everybody is so enthusiastic? The huntsmen explains that they have all gathered to greet the king, who was absent for a long time but has now returned to the country. When the soldiers asks where the king is it turns out that the huntsman is the king in disguise, and the king promises to supply his needs thereafter, but the soldier must never drink his health without permissi
column6: a renowned soldier, discharged from the army, encounters a huntsman in the woods. they stumble upon a robbers' den.
column7: The Boots of Buffalo Leather  Once upon a time, a poor soldier is gifted a pair of magical buffalo leather boots by an old woman. When he puts them on, he can run faster than the wind. He uses his speed to outwit and outmaneuver a cunning innkeeper who tries to cheat him.  The soldier then encounters a beautiful princess and falls in love with her. However, the king refuses to let him marry her unless he can jump over the castle wall on his horse. The soldier uses the boots' magic speed to jump over the wall and win the princess's hand.  However, the innkeeper returns and steals the boots while the soldier is sleeping. The soldier chases the innkeeper, using his wits to reclaim his boots and expose the innkeeper's treachery. The innkeeper is punished, and the soldier and the princess live happily ever after.
column8: not in KB, the title leads however to build a different tale
column9: The Boots of Buffalo Leather  In a verdant woodland, a seasoned soldier, weary from the battlefields, stumbled upon a huntsman. Both lost in thought, they ventured deeper into the dense undergrowth.  Suddenly, they heard sinister whispers. They followed the sound to a dilapidated house nestled among the trees. A foul stench hung in the air. It was the den of robbers.  Undeterred, the soldier and huntsman drew their weapons and charged into the house. They encountered a gruesome sightâ€”the robbers, their faces obscured by dark hoods, were torturing a helpless old woman.  Enraged, the soldier leapt to her defense. He fought valiantly, his sword gleaming through the shadows. The huntsman, armed with his bow and arrow, provided cover, picking off the robbers one by one.  In the midst of the chaos, the soldier's boots, crafted from the finest buffalo leather, proved invaluable. They protected his feet from the broken glass and sharp objects scattered about the hideout.  As the battle raged, one of the robbers realized the soldier's weaknessâ€”his exposed head. With a cunning move, he hurled a heavy object at the soldier.  But just as the object was about to strike, the huntsman's arrow pierced the robber's hand, sending the projectile harmlessly to the ground. The soldier, grateful for his ally's intervention, pressed on with renewed vigor.  One by one, the robbers fell, until only one remained. Desperate, he tried to escape through a hidden back door. But the soldier, his boots giving him exceptional speed, chased after him.  With a swift thrust of his sword, the soldier felled the last robber. The old woman, freed from her captors, wept tears of joy.  In recognition of their bravery, the townspeople showered the soldier and huntsman with praise. And so, the soldier known as the one with the Boots of Buffalo Leather became a legend, a symbol of justice and heroism in the land.
column10: issues led the model to mostly summarise the correct story, instead of a creative retelling, but the final twist is missing

column3: A tailor is preparing to eat some jam, but when flies settle on it, he kills seven of them with one blow of his hand. He makes a belt describing the deed, reading "Seven at One Blow". Inspired, he sets out into the world to seek his fortune. The tailor meets a giant who assumes that "Seven at One Blow" refers to seven men. The giant challenges the tailor. When the giant squeezes water from a boulder, the tailor squeezes milk, or whey, from cheese. The giant throws a rock far into the air, and it eventually lands. The tailor counters the feat by tossing a bird that flies away into the sky; the giant believes the small bird is a "rock" which is thrown so far that it never lands. Later, the giant asks the tailor to help him carry a tree. The tailor directs the giant to carry the trunk, while the tailor will carry the branches. Instead, the tailor climbs on, so the giant carries him as well, but it appears as if the tailor is supporting the branches.Impressed, the giant brings the tailor to the giant's home, where other giants live as well. During the night, the giant attempts to kill the tailor by bashing the bed. However, the tailor, having found the bed too large, had slept in the corner. Upon returning and seeing the tailor alive, the other giants flee in fear of the small man.The tailor enters the royal service, but the other soldiers are afraid that he will lose his temper someday, and then seven of them might die with every blow. They tell the king that either the tailor leaves military service or they will. Afraid of being killed for sending him away, the king instead attempts to get rid of the tailor by sending him to defeat two giants along with a hundred horsemen, offering him half his kingdom and his daughter's hand in marriage if the tailor can kill the giants. By throwing rocks at the two giants while they sleep, the tailor provokes the pair into fighting each other until they kill each other, at which time the tailor stabs the giants in their hearts.The king, surprised the tailor has succeeded, balks on his promise, and requires more of the tailor before he may claim his rewards. The king next sends him after a unicorn, another seemingly impossible task, but the tailor traps it by standing before a tree, so that when the unicorn charges, he steps aside and it drives its horn into the trunk. The king subsequently sends him after a wild boar, but the tailor traps it in a chapel with a similar luring technique.Duly impressed, the king relents, marries the tailor to the princess, and makes the tailor the ruler of half the original kingdom. The tailor's new wife hears him talking in his sleep and realizes with fury that he was merely a tailor and not a noble hero. Upon the princess's demands, the king promises to have him killed or carried off. A squire warns the tailor of the king's plan. While the king's servants are outside the door, the brave little tailor pretends to be talking in his sleep and says "Boy, make the jacket for me, and patch the trousers, or I will hit you across your ears with a yardstick! I have struck down seven with one blow, killed two giants, led away a unicorn, and captured a wild boar, and I am supposed to be afraid of those who are standing just outside the bedroom!" Terrified, the king's servants leave. The king does not try to assassinate the tailor again and so the tailor lives out his days as a king in his own right.
column6: a skilled tailor, known for his deed of killing seven flies at once, embarks on a journey to seek his fortune. along the way, he outwits a giant and eventually marries a princess
column7: In the Grimm fairy tale "The Brave Little Tailor," a young tailor kills seven flies in one blow and boasts about it, claiming to have killed seven with one blow. This boast spreads, and a giant hears of it and decides to put the tailor's courage to the test.  The giant challenges the tailor to a contest of strength, and the tailor bravely accepts. He uses his quick wit and cunning to outsmart and defeat the giant by throwing stones at him, making him fall from a cherry tree, and finally putting his sword in his head.  The tailor then takes the giant's belt, which says "Seven at one blow," and wears it as a trophy. He goes on to encounter two other giants, and using the same tactics, he outsmarts and defeats them as well.  The tailor's bravery and cunning become known throughout the land, and he is praised as a hero. He marries the princess and becomes a successful and respected man.
column8: details are wrong but broad outline is right
column9: The Brave Little Tailor  In a quaint village, there lived a skilled tailor named Tom, renowned for his extraordinary deed of slaying seven flies with one blow. Driven by a thirst for adventure, Tom set off into the world to seek his fortune.  As he ventured through a dense forest, he stumbled upon the abode of a fearsome giant. The giant, a hulking brute, boasted a voracious appetite and terrorized the countryside. Undeterred, Tom devised a cunning plan.  With a piece of chalk, he drew seven circles on his coat and boldly strode into the giant's home. To his surprise, the giant believed Tom to be a mighty warrior due to the chalk marks. Fearful for his safety, the giant fled his home, leaving Tom in possession of his vast treasure.  Emboldened by his success, Tom continued his journey. He came upon a magnificent castle where the king had offered his daughter's hand in marriage to whoever could perform three seemingly impossible tasks. With his wit and resourcefulness, Tom outsmarted the king's cunning riddles and valiant courtiers.  Finally, Tom faced the ultimate test: slaying the dragon that terrorized the kingdom. Using his sharp scissors as a weapon, he deftly outmaneuvered the monstrous beast, reclaiming the princess and winning her heart.  And so, the brave little tailor, once mocked for his small stature, became a legend throughout the land. He married the princess, inherited the kingdom, and ruled wisely for many years, forever proving that even the smallest of beings can achieve extraordinary things with courage and determination.
column10: moral, stereotypicality in choosing the adventure the tailor faces

column1: the bright sun brings it to light
column3: a tailor's apprentice robs and murders a jew on the road, despite the jew saying he has nothing worth stealing. as the jew dies, he warns, "the bright sun will bring it to light."  the man then settles down.  one day, he sees the sunlight reflecting from his coffee and jeers about its bringing "it" to light.  his wife bothers him until he tells her what he means. she gossips about it, and he is arrested and executed.
column5: road, home of the tailor's apprentice,
column6: a tailor's apprentice robs and murders a jew on the road. the apprentice's carelessness eventually reveals the truth.
column7: Summary of "The Bright Sun Brings It to Light"  A king marries a beautiful princess, but she secretly bears a child to a stable boy. The king is furious and orders the boy to be killed. The queen begs for mercy, so instead, the boy is taken deep into the forest and left to die.  Meanwhile, a poor woodcutter finds the baby and takes pity on him. He names him Bright Sun and raises him as his own. Years later, Bright Sun meets the princess and falls in love with her.  The queen recognizes Bright Sun as her son from a birthmark on his shoulder. She goes to the king and reveals the truth of his birth. The king is overjoyed and welcomes Bright Sun as his heir.  The wicked witch who had helped the queen hide her secret is punished by being burned at the stake. The princess and Bright Sun marry and live happily ever after.
column9: The Bright Sun Brings It to Light  As the bright sun cast golden rays upon the dusty road, a young tailor's apprentice named Edmund stumbled along. His heart was heavy with guilt, for he had committed a heinous crime.  Days earlier, he had encountered a wealthy jew on the road. Blinded by greed, Edmund had robbed and murdered the innocent man. He had hidden the stolen jewels beneath the floorboards of his modest home.  Edmund's conscience gnawed at him relentlessly. He became paranoid, fearing that his secret would be exposed. In his haste, he had left a small piece of fabric from his tailoring apron at the scene of the crime.  One scorching afternoon, as Edmund sat in his home, the sun streamed through a crack in the curtains. It illuminated the floorboards, revealing an outline where he had concealed the jewels.  Terror coursed through Edmund's veins as he realized his mistake. He had left a glaring clue that could lead to his downfall. Desperation consumed him as he tried to remove the incriminating evidence, but it was too late.  Within hours, the town guards descended upon Edmund's home. They had tracked the missing fabric to his doorstep. Confronted with the stolen jewels, Edmund finally broke down and confessed his crime.  The bright sun, once a symbol of warmth and hope, had become a cruel witness to Edmund's evil deeds. It had brought his secret to light, leading him down a path of justice and retribution.
column10: excessive morality vs. the amorality of the original (de-historicisation)

column3: tired of the cruel mistreatment they endure from their stepmother, who is an evil witch, a brother and sister run away from home, wander off into the countryside, and spend the night in the woods. by morning, the boy is thirsty, so the children go looking for a spring of clear water. however, their stepmother has already discovered their escape and has bewitched all the springs in the forest. the boy is about to drink from one, when his sister hears how its rushing sound says, "whoever drinks from me will become a tiger" (or lion). As the initial feeling of despair passes, the children decide to live in the woods forever. The girl takes care of her brother, and ties her gold chain around his neck. They go to live in a little house deep within the woods and live there happily for some years, until they are disturbed one day by a hunting party and the king himself who has followed the strange deer home. Upon seeing the beautiful girl, he immediately asks her to marry him and she accepts. Thus she becomes queen and they all live happily in the king's castle. Time passes and the queen gives birth to a son.The witch, however, soon discovers that they are still alive, and plots against them. One night, she kills the queen and replaces her with her own disfigured daughter, whom she has transformed to a physical copy of her. When the queen's ghost secretly visits her baby's bedside for three consecutive nights, the king catches on and her stepmother's evil plan is exposed.The queen comes back to life when the king embraces her, and her stepfamily are tried for their crimes. The witch's daughter is banished into the woods where she is eaten by wild animals, and the wicked stepmother herself is burned at the stake. At the exact moment of the witch's death, the deer becomes human again, and at long last the family is reunited, and they lived happily ever after.
column6: brother and sister flee from their cruel stepmother, encountering enchanted springs in the woods. the brother accidentally transforms into a deer, leading to their secluded life until discovered by the king, who marries the sister.
column7: Brother and Sister  In a dark forest, a brother and sister are lost and alone. As nightfall approaches, they find shelter in a hollow tree. The girl, being pure and innocent, prays to God for help.  Meanwhile, a raven sitting on a nearby branch observes them. Hearing the girl's prayer, the raven hatches a plan. It flies to a nearby house and tells the owner, a powerful sorceress, about the lost children.  The sorceress disguised as an old woman approaches the tree and lures the girl outside. She transforms the girl into a dove and imprisons her in a cage. The boy, witnessing his sister's fate, flees in terror.  The boy wanders aimlessly until he encounters a well. As he bends down to drink, a fish advises him to kiss it. He does so, and the fish turns into a handsome prince.  The prince, who is also a skilled hunter, takes the boy under his wing. Together, they track down the sorceress's house. With the help of the dove, who guides them through a magic forest, they confront the sorceress.  The prince outsmarts the sorceress and forces her to return the girl to human form. The brother and sister are reunited, and they all return home safely.  Moral: Faith and virtue are rewarded
column8: title too general, it thinks it's Hansel and Gretel
column9: In a secluded town, there lived a boy and his younger sister under the cruel clutches of their witch stepmother. Her heart twisted with envy, she subjected them to endless torment.One bleak night, the children decided to flee their tormentor. They ventured into the dense woods, hoping to find safety. As they wandered, they stumbled upon a trio of enchanted springs. The brother, parched with thirst, drank from the first spring. To his horror, he instantly transformed into a beautiful deer.Terrified, the sister led her brother, now a captive in his animal form, deeper into the woods. They found a secluded clearing and lived in isolation for many years.Fate had a different path in store. One day, the young King, renowned for his hunting prowess, pursued a stag into the clearing. As he raised his bow, he noticed the distinctive pendant around the deer's neck—it was his sister's childhood possession.Astounded, the King recognized the transformed brother and raced to the sister's side. Overjoyed by their reunion, he escorted them back to his castle. The King was instantly bewitched by the sister's beauty and proposed marriage on the spot.The cruel stepmother was banished, her wicked plans thwarted. And so, the brother and sister, once refugees fleeing their torment, found solace and happiness in the arms of the King and Queen.

column3: a wealthy gentleman's wife falls gravely ill, and as she lies on her deathbed, she calls for her only daughter, and tells her to remain good and kind, as god would protect her. she then dies and is buried. the child visits her mother's grave every day to grieve and a year goes by. the gentleman marries another woman with two older daughters from a previous marriage. they have beautiful faces and fair skin, but their hearts are cruel and wicked. the stepsisters steal the girl's fine clothes and jewels and force her to wear rags. they banish her into the kitchen, and give her the nickname "aschenputtel" ("ashfool"). she is forced to do all kinds of hard work from dawn to dusk for the sisters. the cruel sisters do nothing but mock her and make her chores harder by creating messes. however, despite all of it, the girl remains good and kind, and regularly visits her mother's grave to cry and pray to god that she will see her circumstances improve.
column6: cinderella suffers mistreatment from her evil stepmother and stepsisters. with the help of magical aid, she attends a royal festival, captivating the prince with her beauty and grace.
column7: In the Grimm fairy tale "Cinderella," a young orphaned girl lives in servitude to her cruel stepmother and stepsisters. Despite her mistreatment, Cinderella remains kind and compassionate.  One day, the prince holds a grand ball, and Cinderella's stepsisters are invited. Cinderella is forbidden to attend, but with the help of her Fairy Godmother, she is transformed into a beautiful princess.  At the ball, Cinderella and the prince fall deeply in love. However, at midnight, Cinderella must return home and leaves behind a glass slipper. The prince, determined to find his beloved, searches the kingdom for the woman who fits the slipper.  When the prince arrives at Cinderella's house, her stepsisters try to hide her, but the glass slipper fits her perfectly. Cinderella and the prince reunite and marry, living happily ever after.
column9: In a humble village nestled amidst rolling hills, there lived a gentle soul named Cinderella. Her life was marred by the cruelty of her stepmother and stepsisters, who treated her like a mere servant. Forced into endless chores, Cinderella found solace in her dreams.  One fateful evening, as the clock struck midnight, news spread of a grand festival at the King's Castle. The stepmother and stepsisters, decked in their finest gowns, departed, gleefully leaving Cinderella behind.  With tears in her eyes, Cinderella retreated to her father's grave in the nearby graveyard. As she wept, a shimmering light appeared, illuminating the tomb. From within emerged her Fairy Godmother, a kind and compassionate spirit.  "Do not despair, child," the Fairy Godmother said. "You shall attend the festival with my help." And with a wave of her wand, Cinderella's rags transformed into an exquisite gown, her wooden clogs into shimmering glass slippers.  As Cinderella arrived at the castle, her presence captivated the Prince. They danced the night away, lost in each other's embrace. But as the clock struck midnight once more, Cinderella fled, leaving behind a single glass slipper.  Driven by love and determination, the Prince searched high and low for the mysterious maiden. Finally, he came to Cinderella's humble abode and, to his delight, found her to be the perfect fit for the glass slipper.  Cinderella and the Prince were married in a grand ceremony, forever ending her days of servitude. From that day forward, they lived happily ever after, a testament to the triumph of kindness and the power of a single wish.

column3: a proud princess set a riddle to her wooers and sent them away when they could not answer.  three tailors came.  two were known for their cleverness and skill, and the third for his uselessness.  the princess asked them what two colors were her hairs.  the first said black and white

column6: tailor 3 wants solves an enigma  to marry the princess . he also also to survive a night with a bear, however.
column7: A poor tailor accidentally kills seven flies with one blow. To boast of his prowess, he embroiders "Seven at one stroke" on his belt. While traveling, he encounters a giant who doubts his story.  The tailor tricks the giant into the forest and pretends to kill a tree by whistling. The giant is impressed and offers him a job to catch a wild boar. The tailor traps the boar in a nearby chapel. The giant is convinced of the tailor's strength and offers him a third task to tie up a unicorn.  The tailor catches the unicorn in a tree and tells the giant to shoot it from afar. The giant succeeds but foolishly gets close to the unicorn, allowing the tailor to tie it up with the giant's own belt.  The tailor returns to the giant's cave and threatens him. The giant flees, leaving his treasures behind. The tailor claims the treasure and marries a princess, boasting about his "Seven at one stroke" all the way.
column8: gets confuse with another fairytale with a tailor
column9: The Clever Little Tailor  There was once a kingdom ruled by a wise and beautiful princess. She announced that she would only marry a man who could solve a cunning enigma and survive a night with a fearsome bear.  Three tailors heard of the challenge. Tailor 1 approached the princess and confidently stated, "I can solve any enigma!" But he failed to do so. Tailor 2 bragged, "I am fearless in the face of danger!" But he was so scared by the bear that he ran away screaming.  Finally, it was Tailor 3's turn. He was a clever and resourceful young man. He went to the princess and said, "I believe I can solve your enigma and survive the night with the bear."  The princess smiled and presented him with the enigma: "What is lighter than a feather, yet the strongest man cannot hold it for more than five minutes?"  Tailor 3 pondered for a moment before answering, "Your breath."  The princess was impressed. She then led Tailor 3 to a deep, dark forest where the bear's den was hidden.  Tailor 3 entered the den with a chuckle. As darkness enveloped him, he heard the heavy breathing and growls of the bear. He knew he had to think quickly.  Tailor 3 took out a piece of thread and tied it around the bear's paw. He then attached the other end to his own leg. As the bear tossed and turned, it pulled on the thread, which in turn woke Tailor 3.  All night long, Tailor 3 stayed vigilant, shifting his weight whenever the bear moved. As dawn broke, the bear fell asleep from exhaustion. Tailor 3 gently removed the thread and escaped from the den.  Exhausted but overjoyed, Tailor 3 returned to the castle. The princess was filled with wonder and gratitude. She kept her promise and married the clever little tailor, who lived a long and happy life at her side.
